item.title: Ruling Party of Myanmar Ousts Its Leader Amid a Government Reshuffle
item.description: The party’s leadership did not explain the underlying reasons for the change, but the ouster appeared to be a struggle for power.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Thura Shwe Mann, right, was seen as a leading candidate for president in the coming elections. Conservative forces in the military were thought to be uncomfortable with his informal alliance with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace laureate and opposition leader.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scenes From the Deadly Explosions in Tianjin
item.description: When news of the blasts emerged late Wednesday, Chinese turned to social media to post images of the destruction, find updates on casualties and offer support to victims and firefighters tackling the huge blaze.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Debris near the site of the explosions at an industrial area in Tianjin, China, on Thursday.

item.title: Tianjin Explosions Leave Warehouse District a Smoky Ruin
item.description: The death toll in the Chinese port city has hit 44 after two overnight blasts, which burned countless cars, shattered windows for blocks and injured hundreds of people.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Rows of burned-out Volkswagen cars near the site of a pair of explosions in Tianjin, China, on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Gearing Up and Locking Down Ahead of Victory Parade
item.description: Here are some of the measures that can be expected to affect Beijing residents and visitors in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: Paramilitary police and members of a gun salute team at a training session in Beijing this month for the military parade celebrating the end of World War II.

item.title: ISIS Enshrines a Theology of Rape
item.description: Claiming the Quran’s support, the Islamic State codifies sex slavery in conquered regions of Iraq and Syria and uses the practice as a recruiting tool.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: In Crimea, a Disputed Beach Is a Symbol of Corruption
item.description: Residents of Gurzuf, once a famous retreat for artists, have expressed frustration that in both Ukraine and now seemingly in Russia, citizens come last.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunbathers at Gurovskiye Kamni beach on the Black Sea in Gurzuf, on the southern coast of Crimea. Access to the beach has become a matter of dispute, with the nearby Kremlin-backed children's camp of Artek seeking to take the beach for its visitors and local residents fighting to keep it open to the public.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scenes From the Deadly Explosions in Tianjin
item.description: When news of the blasts emerged late Wednesday, Chinese turned to social media to post images of the destruction, find updates on casualties and offer support to victims and firefighters tackling the huge blaze.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Teasing Out Ai Weiwei’s Endgame, After China Lifts a Travel Ban
item.description: Mr. Ai has said things to German news media that have horrified his fans, who saw him as a voice of resistance to tyranny.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Ai Weiwei in his workshop in Berlin last week, among stools that were featured in his 2014 show "Evidence" at the Martin-Gropius-Bau exhibition hall.

item.title: Tianjin, a Port in China, Is Rocked by Explosions That Killed Dozens
item.description: At least 44 died and hundreds were reported injured in the blasts, which caused a huge fireball in the city, about 90 miles east of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Explosions at a hazardous goods warehouse on Wednesday killed at least 44 people in the northeast port city of Tianjin.

item.title: Influential Leader in Myanmar Is Removed as Chairman of Governing Party
item.description: The move was the most visible sign yet of splintering among members of Myanmar’s military elite.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER and WAI MOE
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Thura Shwe Mann, right, was seen as a leading candidate for president in the coming elections. Conservative forces in the military were uncomfortable with his informal alliance with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace laureate and opposition leader.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Nick Holdstock on Xinjiang and ‘China’s Forgotten People’
item.description: Nick Holdstock, who spent a year as an English teacher in the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang and then wrote “The Tree That Bleeds: A Uighur Town on the Edge,” discusses terrorism, Uighur popular music and Xinjiang’s changing demographics.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: As Drug Kingpins Fall in Mexico, Cartels Fracture and Violence Surges
item.description: For years, the government has tried to decapitate drug cartels by capturing or killing their leaders. But the organizations are often replaced by smaller, even more vicious groups.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of a community defense force in Petaquillas, Mexico. The groups have sprung up in Guerrero State as a response to corruption and police inaction in the face of gang violence.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Boko Haram Is Said to Have a New Leader
item.description: The leader of Boko Haram has been wounded and replaced, the president of Chad said in a state radio broadcast Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Cease-Fire Is Imperiled as Fighting Erupts
item.description: The Ukrainian government and pro-Russian separatists on Wednesday accused each other of attempting to break a six-month-old peace agreement.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Chinese Media, a Rebuff to Officials Who Won’t Fully Retire
item.description: In a commentary, People’s Daily argued that rather than try to cling to power, retired officials should “cool off” just like a cup of tea after a guest has left.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Jiang Zemin, left, the former president, former Communist Party general secretary and former chairman of the Central Military Commission, with Xi Jinping, who currently holds all three positions, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing in September 2014.

item.title: U.S. Says Iranian Military Figure’s Visit to Russia Violates U.N. Ban
item.description: Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, the head of Iran’s paramilitary Quds force, has been subject to a travel ban since 2007. The visit may provide fuel to opponents of a nuclear agreement with Iran.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Uncredited/Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, right, the head of an Iranian paramilitary force, with Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

item.title: 22-Year Term for Nigerian Who Joined Al Qaeda and Then Denounced It
item.description: A federal judge in Brooklyn said Lawal Babafemi’s recent denunciations of terrorism helped him in receiving less time than guidelines called for.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE CLIFFORD

item.title: U.N. Official Resigns Amid Accusations of Sex Abuse by Peacekeepers
item.description: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, said his head of mission in the Central African Republic, Babacar Gaye, had resigned “at my request.”
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Dengue Fever and Malaria Are Linked to Trash
item.description: The garbage has contaminated the soil and water and attracted infectious pests, the organization, Mercy Corps, said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: North Korea: U.S. Expert Says Uranium Capacity Seems to Be Increasing, Possibly for Nuclear Weapons
item.description: Recent satellite imagery showed that in the last year, North Korea had begun to refurbish a major uranium mill in Pyongsan.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
